title: Monday, 15th April 2019
bodyHTML:
DJ Morning!
11:14 am
BE11:14am

Wait ................

Mouselet Good morning Bryce
BE11:15am

Sorry, I've accidentally hit the lorem ipsum button on the thing I'm trying to file elsewhere.

Blank canvas good morning all
GBKrona Hola - it's semana santa!
BE11:15am

Soundbuy Morning
AMALtd Morning all
11:15 am
BE11:15am

Sigh.

Upaswellasdown morning. Spring has sprung.
BE11:16am

Okay, that's fixed.

DJ Can we do Nyrstar if you like covering failing businesses whose equity is at minimal value?
DogDay Morning all
BE11:17am

Live was so much easier when I didn't have to file 1k words before 11am. But then Tim Berners-Lee came along and ruined newspapers forever.

Upaswellasdown @DJ - isn't Nyrstar's equity now zero?
11:17 am
BE11:17am

Anyway. Where do we begin?

AMALtd is that...? Shall we say Londonum at last?
DJ Mainly interested in what actually happens when a listed holding company owns 2% as contemplated by the restructuring. Like that's stupid they should just be cashed out
Mouselet Good morning. Spring sprung a few days ago; buy Dexcel (makers of cetirizine anti-hayfever pills) (except you can't, it's privately held)
DJ @Up no, they retain 2% but the continued listing makes no sense. So much admin headache and expense
Mouselet https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/technology-47933521 | information commissioner suggests that giant internet companies do not use casino nudge tricks on kids
BE11:18am

Nyrstar? I have to be honest and say I've not read the release yet.

BE11:19am

This one:

11:18 am
BE11:19am

BE11:19am

Neil has though, so read him: https://www.ft.com...-a27a-fdd51850994c

BE11:19am

Commodity trader Trafigura has announced plans to take control of Nyrstar, Europe’s biggest zinc producer, through a complex debt restructuring deal that will safeguard more than 4,000 jobs.

DJ @BE that's the one. Assets sold off to restructured NewCo owned by Trafigura, but listed holding company retains 2% stake in NewCo
Mouselet What is the effect on capitalists of the proposal to make evicting tenants slightly less trivial?
GBKrona Starters gun fired on US-EU trade talks - rocky times ahead for EU (German) auto manufacturers and their suppliers?
11:19 am
BE11:20am

That's good! Safeguarding jobs is good, even when they're commodity traders, who are quite often the missing link.

BE11:20am

Under the proposed recapitalisation, Nyrstar’s creditors are being asked to swap their debt for perpetual securities and other instruments issued by Trafigura.

The move would hand control of Nyrstar to the world’s second biggest metals trader, but only if it can secure the support of 75 per cent of its creditors.

Upaswellasdown @ DJ, I agree. Interserve was at least going to have 10% outside the creditors
Mouselet Umm, aren't Nyrstar's jobs actually in mining and smelting whereas Trafigura is more full of commodity trader?
Mouselet I guess the 'more than 4000 jobs' is from the Wikipedia article saying Nyrstar has 4100 employees
BE11:22am

(@Mouselet: are they? I don't know and up until 3 minutes ago I didn't care. Sorry.)

DJ @Up well IRV was going to give 5% (but Coltrane wanted 10%), but the company would remain listed and lenders would own equity in IRV Plc. This is slightly different, as Traf will own equity in a NewCo, and the existing listed entity will hold 2% of NewCo shares. I think...
11:22 am
BE11:23am

Anyway, this looks to have been a zero for ages and it's a story I've not followed so if you want to talk about it you're on your own.

undefined
BE11:23am

That was a fun way to start a Monday, right? Let's try something else.

11:23 am
BE11:24am

There's Indivior, currently rallying hard.

Indivior PLC (INDV:LSE): Last: 42.79, up 7.56 (+21.46%), High: 42.80, Low: 36.30, Volume: 12.01m
BE11:25am

.... which seems to be on not much. There's a Bernstein note rattling around saying the $3bn of fines will likely move lower .......

FATDAZ morning all
11:26 am
BE11:26am

... and calculating a total value of sales over 2010 to 2014 for Suboxone Film of $2.9bn.

Upaswellasdown @DJ, you're right. Yes, Nyrstar structure sounds pointlessly complicated
AMALtd What's the news on that? Is RB going to be impacted by the fine at all? or Purdue sniffing got short-sellers rushing in?
wayneJ Wasn't Nyrstar itself the creation of a merger of Umicore and Zinifex's zinc smelting operations. Wondering what impact on Umicore if any?
BE11:27am

......... which, yes, true. But why 2014? That's because it's when the Reckitt spinoff was completed.

BE11:28am

We're seeing Indivior through the lens of Reckitt, because the latter -- quite frankly -- has the better analysts.

11:28 am
BE11:28am

Here, for example, is Barclays talking about Reckitt exposure.

BE11:29am

We think that it is unlikely that RB faces criminal charges in the US over alleged Suboxone Film mis-selling. In turn this likely removes WIC disbarment as a risk. While civil action is still ongoing, the federal government has asked for repeated extensions, and similar cases set a precedent for RB not being liable for alleged offenses committed by Indivior. Overall we think RB’s legal risks in the US are considerably smaller than we feared.

BE11:29am

WIC is the Women, Infants and Children nutrition reimbursement programme, in case you're unfamiliar.

11:29 am
BE11:30am

Which is a significant bit of Mead Johnson.

BE11:30am

Indivior, and only Indivior, has been indicted by a federal grand jury on criminal charges. Agrand jury indictment is a pre-requisitefor bringing federalcriminal charges in the US. We therefore view it as a significant positive that a grand jury examined the evidence in this case and decided that only Indivior should face criminal charges, and that RB has not been charged. We believe a criminal conviction is in turn likely a pre-requisite for RB being barred from the US WIC infant formula programme

BE11:30am

RB is currently a defendant (alongside Indivior) in an ongoing civil law action. RB has previously (alongside Indivior) faced civil action over Suboxone Film allegations.In October 2017 a judge ruled that RB “cannot be held liable simply due to its former corporate relationship to Indivior” and dismissed anti-trust litigation brought by the State of Wisconsin and others against RB. While there may be technical differencesin this case it is a helpful precedent.

11:30 am
Reckitt Benckiser Group PLC (RB.:LSE): Last: 5,860, down 45 (-0.76%), High: 5,933, Low: 5,808, Volume: 438.48k
wayneJ Re RB / Indivior - depends on if the directors can show that they acted on an informed basis in good faith in enabling the spin-off
BE11:32am

They're pro Reckitt, saying it's cheap, though with the Kraft Heinz-Lite strategy currently in disarray and and boardroom churn on top of the litigation risk it's not difficult to see why it's cheap.

red any umicore dips should be bought. its a divi paying slow burner that will go like a firecracker once ev hits terminal velocity
wayneJ Both RB and Indivior have ADRs but not sure if they are sponsored. If they have raised monies or done US SEC filings then even more 'interesting'
Mouselet I shouldn't expect that the fate of a division divested in 2007 will do much to umicore
BE11:33am

Quick recap from RBC from last week to say everything's uncertain and then we'll move on.

11:33 am
BE11:33am

Key things to note: i) Most of the allegations were from the pre-merger time, so before 2014, when INDV was still part of Reckitt Benckiser (Reckitt Benckiser Pharmaceuticals); ii) Indivior was in advanced negotiations with DOJ and had in its accounts $438m provision for settlement, an amount Indivior believed to fairly cover the charges upon which it was alleged; and iii) Indivior could still come to terms and settle with DOJ or decide to fight to court (in which case it could be 12 months until the court hearing). Overall, Indivior believes it has a strong case and the demands placed by DOJ during settlement discussions were far beyond what company thought was fair and supported by evidence and not just on the monetary side (to which a structured settlement could have been an option where Indivior pays over time) but also with regards to certain terms and conditions which may have been unattainable and not in the best interest of its shareholders.
What now? It is difficult to know the most likely outcome. Indivior will continue to seek settlement with DOJ in the first place if demands by DOJ are such that will allow Indivior to continue sell its products. In the event of no settlement Indivior’s might decide to go into court and let the jury decide the verdict. We are not legal experts and whilst Indivior has a lot of evidence that supports its work to fight opioid addiction it’s uncertain how the jury will view and decide on the old events before de-merger. In addition we have no visibility on the de-merger clauses and whether one or both companies (Indivior and Reckitt Benckiser) will be held liable and to what amount the final changes could come up to. In summary, this is a very material uncertainty that will remain an overhang for the foreseeable future.

undefined
BE11:34am

Garbage M&A.

11:34 am
BE11:34am

Waste Management to Acquire Advanced Disposal for $4.9 Billion Adding Complementary Assets and Customer Base in the Eastern United States

BE11:35am

22.1% premium.

Viking1 Morning
BE11:36am

Release is over here if you want some nice slides about US landfill: https://www.busine...sposal-4.9-Billion

11:36 am
undefined
youngone Any follow through on HMSO? from friday
wayneJ Anyone interested - worth looking at Windstream's spinoff and sale / leaseback to Uniti. A lesson in how spinoffs can go wrong.
BE11:37am

(@Youngone: denied.)

BE11:38am

IWG -- née Regus -- doing well on its first franchise sale thing.

11:38 am
BE11:38am

This is the Mark Dixon's Plan B having failed to get the price he wanted from PE.

BE11:39am

Or rather, the price on which the board could agree. So he's flogged Japan in a sort of sale-and-franchise structure for a pretty impressive price.

IWG Plc (IWG:LSE): Last: 337.20, up 61.5 (+22.31%), High: 338.70, Low: 305.10, Volume: 5.12m
wayneJ Also a link worth following on spinoffs - https://www.gibsondunn.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/11/WebcastSlides-Potential-Pitfalls-and-Liabilities-in-Spin-Off-Transactions-31-October-2017.pdf
11:39 am
BE11:40am

Peel Hunt's good here.

BE11:40am

IWG has sold its first franchise for more than double our bestcase
estimate. Japan only contributed 4% of group EBITDA (net
of an estimate for its continuing contribution) yet has been sold
for £320m cash, more than 11% of group EV. More sales will
follow, which should further validate the new strategy, release
substantial value and lead to a complete re-appraisal of the
company. Special dividends or cash returns seem likely. Because
this is only one transaction, we limit ourselves to increasing our
TP from 351p to 400p.

BE11:40am

So, sale at 3.4x revenue and 3.3x gross assets

11:40 am
BE11:40am

But with IWG retaining an 5% EBITA margin on system sales

BE11:41am

Meaning the business has gone for 20x FY18 EBITDA

BE11:41am

Vs Regus itself at 7.6x FY18 EBITDA

11:41 am
BE11:41am

(At least at the start of the day.)

BE11:42am

The question is how far investors should extrapolate. We do not view this as a one-off, given that the group is seeing a lot of interest from multiple investors, and revise our TP to 400p to account for it. This may prove to be far too conservative, because (i) our TP is still 55% weighted to a low-ball fundamental fair value of 239p, when this might look increasingly irrelevant, and (ii) it still only assumes that no other region is sold for more than 1.5x revenue (we simply changed our probabilities).

BE11:42am

Should note that Japan is higher margin than the group average, at 21% vs 15%. Still .......

Tom Dalgleish Wayne that was my point last week. That sometimes the spinner knows something that it wants off the books
11:43 am
BE11:43am

Coincidentally, Credit Suisse moved from outperform from underperform shortly before the news based on an analysis of franchising.

BE11:44am

There is a lot going on at IWG. But we think the key change is the strategic pivot towards a franchise business. Within the report we look at a number of scenarios and run sensitivity on how this process could develop in the coming years. It is early in the process with limited
tangible progress but management is clear that it has received significant
interest at attractive prices for certain IWG assets. Selling mature centres will negatively impact PTP but reduce debt, raise ROIC and improve the quality of earnings. We estimate that the sale of 500 mature centres in 2020E would reduce PTP by 12% but cut debt by c90% and raise ROIC from c.10% to c15% (all pre IFRS 16), which we expect to drive positive valuation re-rating. Assuming constant relationship between ROIC and EV/EBITDA multiple this would boost the share price by 37% In addition IWG’s hybrid co-working brand has grown significantly

wayneJ @Tom - agreed (sorry still catching up on last week). The issue for a spinner is whether there is evidential evidence or deliberate 'blindness' etc
undefined
Tom Dalgleish Wayne it may only be they see bad trading ahead
11:47 am
BE11:47am

What else? It's the four day Easter week, its Monday, there was nothing of consequence in the Sundays and there's not a lot of corporate on the tape ....

Viking1 And PM travelling back and forth
BE11:48am

Oh, and -- lucky me! -- I'm understudy on the Neil Collins column for Friday.

Viking1 And no PM ...
BE11:49am

If anyone has any idea what on earth I should be writing about, by all means suggest.

Irish HF guy Re Spinoff's etc, RRD and its 2 spinouts, DFIN and LNC interesting case. Debt burden in RRD is nearly $2bn, equity value $330m LNC now merging with Quad Graphics, all stock merger. I am unable to see how debt can be left at parent company level with a declining business, but hey, I am just an old fashioned accountant!
Upaswellasdown @Wayne: https://www.sec.gov/cgi-bin/browse-edgar?company=reckitt+benckiser&owner=exclude&action=getcompany
11:49 am

bryce dot elder @ft.com .... Go on, send me your rambling emails about why Sirius Minerals is being suppressed by evil market makers or whatever.

Caz saying the SVT price cap has gone wrong.

wayneJ @Irish - interesting - but don't u mean LSC Communications (Rather than LNC)? Good question.
Upaswellasdown Is anyone else staying off social media today to avoid any spoilers on GoT?

The idea was that it'd flatten out market pricing and British Gas would lose fewer customers.

K-NUCK bryce dot elder @ft.com - i got a bounce back...
wayneJ @Upaswell - re RB/ - looks like they have done ad hoc filings rather than routine in the US? Not sure if that puts them under risk of US courts.
K-NUCK oh! its a actual dot. Got it.
Viking1 Trump’s tweet this morning ref : how to change Boeing • "What do I know about branding," tweets President Trump. "Maybe nothing (but I did become president)."• Trump's 3-point plan: Fix the 737 MAX, add some great additional features, and REBRAND the plane with a new name.• "No product has suffered like this one. But again, what the hell do I know."
Soundbuy You could pen a few hundred words re kraftliner pricing..............
BE11:53am

However, gas prices spiked higher in Q3 2018 and a lot of new entrants have appeared over the last few months.

11:53 am
BE11:53am

All of whom are doing the land-grab thing.

BE11:54am

Or the ponzi marketing thing where you get £50 for recruiting customers, etc.

BE11:54am

Upaswellasdown @Wayne, don't know. They also sold 144a USD bonds to fund Mead Johnson acqn
11:54 am
BE11:55am

While early data broadly supported our bullish thesis, the level of pricing dispersion in UK energy offers has jumped sharply from ~£150/cust to greater than £300/cust in recent weeks. As a result, we expect customer switching levels to remain elevated, forcing incumbent retailers to offer deeply discounted products to retain market share. We have accordingly
trimmed our medium term margin expectations. Long term, the
decision to protect market share (at the expense of margins) in our
view may play out favourably, but at the expense of near-term
earnings. License changes designed to lower the level of risk taken
by smaller suppliers will be supportive, but the consultation is now
expected to drag through the summer.

wayneJ @Upaswell - grief - had forgotten about Mead Johnson. Not sure re 144a's - IIRC the very point of them is that they do not require full US registration.
BE11:56am

Plus you have nice-ish weather in Q1, and nuclear power stations going offline, and upstream softening a bit, so Centrica forecasts move down once more.

BE11:56am

Including the 2019 divi, which goes from 8p to 7p,

Airborne Cigar @Upaswell - GoT - wouldn't know how to find GoT if I wanted to. Isn't it behind some sort of paywall?
11:57 am
BE11:57am

The writing has been on the wall for the dividend since the 2018 results in
February, but outside an abrupt change of fortunes we see earnings
and cash flow expectations retreating in the lead-up to the interim
result in July. We are downgrading to Neutral with revised 125p
Price Target.

Tom Dalgleish Anyone inclined to short UBER come the day?

Start late and still run out of stuff before midday .... sheesh, Mondays huh.

BE12:00pm

Mouselet mentions rental reform.

wayneJ Are the power generators / distributors in the UK overlevered given the uncertainity of their business models and increasing competition?
BornCynic Thanks for Centrica BE
BE12:01pm

And making it tougher to evict people. https://www.ft.com...-939a-341f5ada9d40

BE12:01pm

Landlords will no longer be able to evict tenants at short notice without giving a reason, under reforms proposed by the government on Monday.

James Brokenshire, the communities secretary, said he would consult on new legislation to abolish “no-fault” evictions, which enable landlords to throw out their tenants with eight weeks’ notice without explaining why.

12:01 pm
BE12:02pm

The National Landlords Association, which represents private residential landlords, criticised the proposals.

“Landlords currently have little choice but to use Section 21,” said Richard Lambert, NLA chief executive. “They have no confidence in the ability or the capacity of the courts to deal with possession claims quickly and surely, regardless of the strength of the landlord’s case.

FATDAZ @wayneJ that's a good question we probably won't get too much insight on that until the next time we have to upgrade the infrastructure (nuclear aside)
BE12:02pm

Imagine being a member of The National Landlords Association. Imagine the clammy coldness emanating from every AGM.

Viking1 Just remembered Thursday is an bank Holliday in most of Europe
